cohere_generated_answer: Variations in atmospheric pressure create differences in pressure from one location to another, causing air to move from high-pressure areas to low-pressure areas, resulting in wind formation. Even small differences in pressure can have a significant impact on wind direction and velocity. This movement of air is called the general circulation of the atmosphere and is influenced by factors such as latitudinal variations in heating, the emergence of pressure belts, the rotation of the Earth, and the distribution of continents and oceans. The Coriolis effect, caused by the Earth's rotation, also influences wind direction, deflecting winds to the right in the Northern Hemisphere and to the left in the Southern Hemisphere.
